channel.title: tastytrade: Market Measures
channel.description: It's not always easy to take the measure of a market, whether you've been trading for a day or a decade. On this segment we look under the hood—options probabilities, volatility, trading strategies, futures, you name it—so your trading mechanics are built to manage more winners.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Tom and Bat present research on the market, examining probabilities, volatility, strategies, and more.

item.title: Product Indifference
item.description:
The results from selling strangles across unrelated and generally uncorrelated underlyings were very similar when the delta, premium, and price of the underlying were considered. 

We can form the following conjecture based on these results: the only tangible differences between underlyings that affect risk and return are the prices and IVs of the underlyings in question.

item.title: Relationship between POP Delta and Volatility
item.description:
When selling premium, one minus delta has been shown as being a good proxy for the probability of profit (POP).

If you sold a 30 delta put, you would expect to have roughly a 70% POP. We use this simple calculation every day when placing trades, but does this relationship for delta and POP hold even as volatility changes?

item.title: How Theta and IV are Correlated
item.description: 30 delta strangles have roughly 2x the theta of a 10 delta strangle and roughly 1.5x the theta of a 20 delta strangle. Theta and IV scale 1 to 1, meaning theta and implied volatility can be used as substitutes when analyzing the premium of the trade.In 2008 and 2020 (years in which IVs were about the same), we could lock in 3x the theta compared to long term averages and around 4 to 5 times compared to today’s IV environment.

item.title: Historical Crypto Rallies
item.description:
Crypto is becoming a huge asset class. Retail traders need to understand what their portfolio crypto exposure can lead to in the short and long term.

The global crypto market cap has grown to $2.76 Trillion, up 30% from the Market Measures segment about historical crypto drawdowns.

For the past year, crypto has seen a 10% or greater rally each month. Following these moves, there are normally corrections before the next surge.

item.title: How Bad Was 2020: Stocks vs Options
item.description:
In the worst short-lived selloff in history, selling naked puts could have seen worse losses than the drawdown in a long stock portfolio, but only if your exposure was large enough.

Because by adding any risk definition (long wings), rolling down calls, diversifying products, and diversifying IVs you would have reduced the drawdown seen in this portfolio, we look at worst-case-scenario on both to make a real comparison.

item.title: Earnings Performance Across Sectors
item.description:
As we round out the halfway point of this 3rd quarter earnings season, we thought it would be interesting to see how 1-day post earnings performance has varied across sectors. Even though earnings have been poor relative to the last quarter, the market is still rallying. It seems that the fundamentals may not be the key driver for market moves.

How have the sectors performed following their earnings? Which sector has had the best performance? Watch to find out!

item.title: How Naked Should My Trade Be?
item.description:
On average, buying wings is a tradeoff between portfolio consistency in the short term, at the expense of long term profitability.

Solely maximizing profitability without considering risk management is the quickest way to get in trouble. For those considering taking some risk off the table, start with 5∆ wings as they have a modest but noticeable reduction in risk/return compared to selling naked.

item.title: Distribution of Implied Volatility
item.description: tastytrade looks at how the distribution of implied volatility has changed since the start of COVID.Over the past 2 years, we have seen extremely high levels of volatility in the markets, seeing the highest ever close in March of 2020. While current VIX levels may seem low relative to what we have seen recently, they are actually near the median of what we saw before COVID. How much has COVID skewed the distribution of implied volatility?

item.title: What Does Buying Wings Do?
item.description:
On average, the cost of insuring a strangle against outlier losses (buying wings) is between 20% and 50% of the price of the long option.

In higher IVR situations, around half of the premium of the long option is used as the “vig” to pay for the outlier protection. In lower IVR, where the size of price moves is lower, the same “vig” will cost around 20% of the long option premium.

item.title: Tradable Crypto Options
item.description: With Bitcoin options taking hold in the retail space, we can compare expected future volatility to what actually happened: IV vs. HV. The spread may narrow over time since SPY’s spread is less than 15% of Bitcoin’s current IV-HV spread.

item.title: How Wide to Make Your Wings
item.description:
While trading strangles is the ideal strategy to stay neutral from a probability of profit (POP) standpoint, in smaller accounts, the buying power requirement (BPR) is sometimes too high.

The solution to this is to trade iron condors. However, the POP of iron condors is less than a strangle, so how can traders adjust the width of their wings to ensure they are still receiving good returns for the risk they are taking? tastytrade digs in.

item.title: Outliers as IV Decreases
item.description:
Lower IV environments tend to have the largest “outlier” P/Ls for undefined risk strategies. With IV rapidly declining, how bad are those outliers as % of initial credit as IV goes down?

The tastytrade research team finds that as implied volatility rises in SPY, the size of the outlier become less severe as a percentage of initial credit.

Also, the probability of seeing an outlier defined in this study on stays more or less consistent over all IV environments, around 2% to 3% on a trade since 2005.

item.title: Crypto Correlation Across Different Volatilities
item.description:
Since there are no options on cryptos, we cannot directly find implied volatility. Instead we look at using Bitcoin’s historical volatility as a proxy for market volatility. Over the past year, we have seen Bitcoin’s volatility rest between 50% and 120%.

In the equity markets, when volatility is high, correlation nears 1. Does this happen in the crypto market as well? In different volatility environments, how correlated are cryptocurrencies to one another?

item.title: The Rate of IV Deflation
item.description:
This recent moderate IV spike has been met by a rapid contraction where premium levels declined by around 40% on average.

Short-lived pops in IV are one of the keys to a premium seller’s success. By staying small over time, it is much easier (financially and psychologically) to scale up during these “pops” and see the above-average decay in action.

item.title: Movements of the S&P Components
item.description:
Over the past two years, the majority of the S&P 500 components have been up 55% of the time. In the same time frame, the S&P itself has been up 58% of the time.

Each component is subject to its own implied volatility, but do different levels of the VIX mean different percentages of components being up or down on that day?

item.title: The Tradeoff of Shorter DTE
item.description:
Through our research, we have shown time and time again that selling premium at 45 DTE provides a well-rounded risk-return...but what happens when we trade lower DTE?

Key Takeaways:

  • Shorter DTE trades should have different entry criteria if you choose to trade them...similar to earnings trades, stay extra small and define risk to sustain the increased trade volatility.
  • There are no observable long-term P/L or win rate advantages to trading a certain DTE, but generally lower DTE trades have tight management windows and require frequent attention.

item.title: Where is the Risk with Nat Gas?
item.description:
Natural gas has remained range bound between 2009 and 2021, but in the last month, broke out to above $6. While it is pulling back now, this acts as an indication to where the risk is when trading natural gas.

With equities, the risk lies to the downside as investors and traders worry about their assets going to zero. With natural gas, the risk lies to the upside because the demand increases much faster than the supply can keep up.

How do calls and puts in UNG compare to calls and puts in SPY, and where does the real risk lie?

item.title: Why Ever Sell Calls?
item.description:
Considering that calls are cheaper to begin with than puts, why would we ever sell calls?

Although calls are cheaper and more susceptible to positive market drift over time, the worst case outlier is far less dangerous than the put side (for SPY). Even in the above-average bull market since 2005, selling 16∆ calls in SPY basically broke even, and the POP was still very high.

item.title: What Happens When a Strangle Gets Tested?
item.description:
As we’ve discussed in previous studies, the probability of touch for a single option is roughly equal to 2 * the delta of the option.

The probability of touch does not necessarily mean that the option will expire in the money, however, the probability of expiring in the money does increase.

Following an option getting tested, what happens next? Does the underlying continue in that direction or does it reverse back?
